org.obrel.core

Class RelationType<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.obrel.core.RelatedObject
      • org.obrel.core.RelationType<T>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ElementAccess<RelationType<T>>, ElementAccessFunction<RelationType<T>,Relatable,T>, java.io.Serializable, java.util.function.Function<Relatable,T>, Relatable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    AutomaticType, ConstraintType, ListenerType, ListType, MapType, SetType, TimerType

    public class RelationType<T>
extends RelatedObject
implements ElementAccessFunction<RelationType<T>,Relatable,T>, java.io.Serializable
    Instances of this class define the type and behavior of relations. The generic type parameter defines the type of the relation's target object. Instances cannot be created directly but must be created through one of the factory methods in the class RelationTypes.

    The names of all relation types must be unique. If an application tries to create a new type instance with a name that already exists an exception will be thrown. To avoid name conflicts or to reuse the names of existing types in a different context applications should prepend type names with a namespace. A namespace is similar to a Java package name, i.e. lower case words that are separated by the point character '.'. Types without a namespace prefix are automatically members of the default (= empty) namespace. The namespace of a type can be queried by means of the method getNamespace(). Although it is not required it is recommended to use the package name of the class that defines a type as the type's namespace too.

    Relation types implement the ElementAccessFunction interface. The implementation of the Function.evaluate(Object) method returns the relation value from a Relatable input object. This allows to use relation types for easy access to relations in function-based APIs.

    All relations types are serializable. Because relation types are defined as singleton instances, subclasses should declare all additional fields that they declare as transient because instances will be replaced by their singleton on deserialization so that all additional data will be lost anyway and serializing them would therefore only have a negative effect.

    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      • RelationType

        public RelationType(java.lang.String sName,
                    java.lang.Class<? super T> rTargetType,

      • RelationType

        public RelationType(java.lang.String sName,
                    java.lang.Class<? super T> rTargetType,
                    Function<? super Relatable,? super T> fDefaultValue,
                    Function<? super Relatable,? super T> fInitialValue,
                    RelationTypeModifier... rModifiers)
        Creates a new instance with a certain name, data types, and flags. The relation type constructors are not public because instances of relation types must be created through one of the the factory methods in the class RelationTypes.

        The generic declaration of the datatype and function arguments has been relaxed to '? super T' to allow Classes and Functions that represent or create generic types, respectively. Because of this there isn't an exact type checking of the datatype parameters and it is the responsibility of the application code to declare relation types with the most specific type possible.

        Parameters:
        sName - The name of the type instance or NULL for automatic name initialization by RelationTypes.init(Class)
        rTargetType - The class of the target value datatype
        fDefaultValue - The default value
        fInitialValue - A function that returns the initial value for relations of this type
        rModifiers - The modifiers to be set on this instance
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the type name is invalid or if a type with the given name exists already

      • RelationType

        protected RelationType(RelationTypeModifier... rModifiers)
        Creates a new instance that is only partially initialized. The defining class must invoke the method RelationTypes.init(Class) from it's static initializer to fully initialize this relation type before it is used.

        The generic declaration of the datatype and function arguments has been relaxed to '? super T' to allow Classes and Functions that represent or create generic types, respectively. Because of this there isn't an exact type checking of the datatype parameters and it is the responsibility of the application code to declare relation types with the most specific type possible.

        Parameters:
        rModifiers - The modifiers to be set on this instance
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the type name is invalid or if a type with the given name exists already

      • RelationType

        protected RelationType(Function<? super Relatable,? super T> fDefaultValue,
                       Function<? super Relatable,? super T> fInitialValue,
                       RelationTypeModifier... rModifiers)
        Creates a new instance that is only partially initialized. The defining class must invoke the method RelationTypes.init(Class) from it's static initializer to fully initialize this relation type before it is used.

        The generic declaration of the datatype and function arguments has been relaxed to '? super T' to allow Classes and Functions that represent or create generic types, respectively. Because of this there isn't an exact type checking of the datatype parameters and it is the responsibility of the application code to declare relation types with the most specific type possible.

        Parameters:
        fDefaultValue - The default value
        fInitialValue - A function that returns the initial value for relations of this type
        rModifiers - The modifiers to be set on this instance
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the type name is invalid or if a type with the given name exists already

      • unregisterRelationType

        public static void unregisterRelationType(RelationType<?> rType)
        Allows to remove a relation type from the global type registry. This method is intended to discard temporary relation types that are no longer needed by an application. Caution: using a unregistered relation type afterwards will have undefined results.
        Parameters:
        rType - The relation type to unregister

      • addTypeListener

        public void addTypeListener(EventHandler<RelationEvent<T>> rListener)
        Adds a listener to relation events in this relation type. This method provides a type-safe interface for adding relation event listeners to the relation with the type ListenerTypes.RELATION_TYPE_LISTENERS. To remove a listener that relation can be modified directly because type safety is not needed then.
        Parameters:
        rListener - The relation event listener to add

        See Also:

      • annotate

        public final <V> RelationType<T> annotate(RelationType<V> rAnnotationType,
                                          V rValue)
        Creates an annotation on this relation type with a certain relation type and value. Annotations are meta-relations that provide additional information about relation types. This method is just a semantic variant of the relatable method Relatable.set(RelationType, Object). The only difference is that it returns the relation type instance instead of the created (meta-) relation to allow the concatenation of annotation calls.
        Parameters:
        rAnnotationType - The relation type of the annotation
        rValue - The annotation value
        Returns:
        Returns this instance to allow concatenation of annotation setting

      • defaultValue

        public T defaultValue(Relatable rParent)
        Returns a default resolved value for relations with this type. This value will be returned if a relation of this type is queried with the method Relatable.get(RelationType) but doesn't exist. This default implementation always returns NULL but subclasses may return arbitrary values of the resolved datatype. It is important to understand that no relation will be created from values that are returned from this method. To initialize non-existing relations on the first access the method initialValue(Relatable) must be overridden instead.

        The method argument is the parent object from which the relation has been queried. Subclasses can use it to create default values that are specific to certain parent object. Subclasses should also create separate instances for default values if the value class is not immutable.

        Parameters:
        rParent - The parent object to return the default value for
        Returns:
        The default value for non-existing relations of this type

      • evaluate

        Implemented to return the relation value for this type from the given input object.
        Parameters:
        rObject - The input value of the function
        Returns:
        The resulting (output) value (may be NULL)
        See Also:
        Function.evaluate(Object)

      • initialValue

        public T initialValue(Relatable rParent)
        Returns the initial target value of relations with this type. This value will be used if a non-existing relation of this type is queried for the first time. If an initial value function has been set and it or a subclass returns a value that is not NULL (which is the default) a new relation will be created with that target value.

        The method argument is the parent object from which the relation has been queried. Subclasses can use it to create initial values that are specific to certain parent object. Subclasses should also create separate instances for initial values if the value class is not immutable.

        Parameters:
        rParent - The parent object of the relation to be initialized
        Returns:
        The initial value for new relations of this type or NULL to suppress the creation of new relations on querying

      • is

        public <O extends Relatable> Predicate<O> is(Predicate<? super T> pComparison)

        Parameters:
        pComparison - The criteria predicate to evaluate the function result
        Returns:
        The function predicate
        See Also:
        Function.is(Predicate)

      • isFinal

        public final boolean isFinal()
        Checks the RelationTypeModifier.FINAL modifier of this type. If this modifier is set it is not possible to modify or delete a relation of this type after it has been set on an object.
        Returns:
        TRUE if relations with this type are final

      • isInitialized

        public final boolean isInitialized()
        Checks whether this type has been fully initialized.
        Returns:
        TRUE if the type is fully initialized

      • isPrivate

        public final boolean isPrivate()
        Checks the RelationTypeModifier.PRIVATE modifier of this type. If this modifier is set relations of this type will not be listed when relations are queried through the methods in the Relatable interface with predicate arguments.
        Returns:
        TRUE if relations with this type are private

      • isReadonly

        public final boolean isReadonly()
        Checks the RelationTypeModifier.READONLY modifier of this type. If this modifier is set it is not possible to modify or delete a relation at all. To be useful a readonly relation type must return a value from it's initialValue(Relatable) method because the only way to create a new relation of such a type is to query it through the method Relatable.get(RelationType).
        Returns:
        TRUE if relations with this type are readonly

      • isTransient

        public final boolean isTransient()
        Checks the RelationTypeModifier.TRANSIENT modifier of this type. If this modifier is set relations of this type will be ignored if a relatable object is serialized.
        Returns:
        TRUE if relations with this type are transient

        Parameters:

        Returns:
        TRUE if the given object is a valid target

      • addRelation

        protected Relation<T> addRelation(Relatable rParent,
                                  Relation<T> rRelation)
        This method will be invoked just before a new relation of this type is added to an object. It may be overridden by subclasses to intercept this. To prevent the addition of the new relation a subclass may throw an exception. Subclasses may also replace the given relation with a different instave if necessary and return that instead.

        Subclasses should always invoke the superclass method. The default implementation currently just returns the input relation.

        Parameters:
        rParent - The parent object of the new relation
        rRelation - The relation to be added to the parent
        Returns:
        The relation to add

      • deleteRelation

        protected void deleteRelation(Relatable rParent,
                              Relation<?> rRelation)
        This method will be invoked just before a relation of this type will be deleted. It may be overridden by subclasses to intercept the deletion of a relation from an object. To prevent the deletion of the relation a subclass may throw an exception.

        Subclasses should normally always invoke the superclass method because it will notify the relation event listeners of this type.

        Parameters:
        rParent - The parent object of the relation
        rRelation - The relation to be deleted
        Throws:
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - If this relation type is final

      • newIntermediateRelation

        protected <I> Relation<T> newIntermediateRelation(RelatedObject rParent,
                                                  Function<I,T> fTargetResolver,
                                                  I rIntermediateTarget)
        Returns a new relation for this type in the given parent object that stores the relation target in an intermediate format until the relation is queried for the first time. The default implementation returns a new instance of IntermediateRelation.
        Parameters:
        rParent - The parent object of the new relation
        fTargetResolver - The function that must be applied to the intermediate target value to resolve the final target value
        rIntermediateTarget - The intermediate target value (must not be NULL)
        Returns:
        The new relation

      • newRelation

        protected Relation<T> newRelation(RelatedObject rParent,
                                  T rTarget)
        Returns a new relation for this type in the given parent object. The default implementation returns a new instance of DirectRelation.
        Parameters:
        rParent - The parent object of the new relation
        rTarget - The target value of the relation
        Returns:
        The new relation

      • newTransformedRelation

        protected <D> TransformedRelation<T,D> newTransformedRelation(RelatedObject rParent,
                                                              InvertibleFunction<T,D> fTransformation)
        Returns a new relation for this type in the given parent object that stores the relation target in a transformed format. The default implementation returns a new instance of TransformedRelation.
        Parameters:
        rParent - The parent object of the new relation
        fTransformation - The transformation to apply to target values
        Returns:
        The new relation

      • prepareRelationUpdate

        protected void prepareRelationUpdate(Relation<T> rRelation,
                                     T rNewTarget)
        This method will be invoked just before a relation of this type is updated. It may be overridden by subclasses to intercept the updating of a relation. To prevent the updating of the relation a subclass may throw an exception. This method does not receive the parent object of a relation because that information may not be available from the current context. If a type needs the parent object of the relation in this method it should set it in the method addRelation(Relatable, Relation) as a relation of type StandardTypes.PARENT when the relation is added.

        Subclasses should normally always invoke the superclass method because it will notify the relation event listeners of this type.

        Parameters:
        rRelation - The relation to be deleted
        rNewTarget - The new target object
        Throws:
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - If this relation type is final

      • readResolve

        protected final java.lang.Object readResolve()
                                      throws java.io.ObjectStreamException
        Returns the type instance that corresponds to the type name that has been read by the deserialization.
        Returns:
        The resolved relation type instance
        Throws:
        java.io.ObjectStreamException - If no type instance exists for the deserialized name

      • setRelationTarget

        protected void setRelationTarget(Relation<T> rRelation,
                                 T rValue)
        Updates the target of a relation with this type to a new value. This method provides the possibility for relation types to update the targets of their relations under certain circumstances (e.g. replacing mutable targets with immutable ones). The code checks that the type of the relations is this instance or else throws an exception.
        Parameters:
        rRelation - The relation to set the target of
        rValue - The new relation target
